metadata./Keywords: Papillary thyroid carcinoma; Solitary fibrous tumor; Mesenchymal tumor
metadata./Title: Synchronous occurrence of papillary thyroid carcinoma and solitary fibrous tumor of the thyroid: a case report
metadata./Producer: Acrobat Distiller 10.1.8 (Windows); modified using iText® 5.3.5 ©2000-2012 1T3XT BVBA (SPRINGER SBM; licensed version)

sections.Background:
Background Solitary fibrous tumors (SFT) are ubiquitous mesenchymal neoplasms of intermediate malignant poten‑
tial. SFTs of the head and neck are rare, representing less than 0.1% of all SFTs. Solitary fibrous tumors of the thyroid 
(SFTT) are even rarer. Only 49 cases of SFTTs have been documented in the literature, with just two cases being syn‑
chronous with papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC). By presenting a synchronous PTC and SFTT case, we aim to review 
the clinical presentation, diagnostic challenges, histopathological characteristics, and management strategies associ‑
ated with this unusual co ‑occurrence.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation A 46‑ year ‑old North African female patient with no prior medical history presented with a year ‑
long, indwelling cervical swelling. Cervical ultrasound revealed two nodules in the right thyroid lobe and one nodule 
in the left thyroid lobe. The first right thyroid nodule, measuring 50 mm, is classified as European Thyroid Imaging 
and Reporting Data System (EU‑ TIRADS) III. The second right thyroid nodule, measuring 15 mm, and the 25 mm left 
thyroid nodule were classified as EU‑ TIRADS IV. A total thyroidectomy with bilateral lymphadenectomy was per ‑
formed. Microscopic examination revealed that the left nodule and right nodule measuring 15 mm corresponded 
to invasive PTCs. The second nodule in the right lobe corresponded to a proliferation of spindle cells arranged 
in sheets and wavy or storiform bundles with a hemangiopericytoma‑like vascular pattern. The spindle cells had 
indistinct boundaries with elongated non‑atypical nuclei. There was no mitosis. On immunochemistry, the spindle 
cells showed strong and diffuse positivity for CD34 and CD99. They are negative for smooth muscle actin, S100, 
and cytokeratin. It was then confirmed to be an SFTT case. The final diagnosis was of synchronous PTC and SFTT.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion We presented the third case of synchronous PTC and SFTT. The co ‑occurrence of these tumors is likely 
incidental. However, further studies are needed to assess the physiopathology and molecular alterations of this 
association.
Keywords  Papillary thyroid carcinoma, Solitary fibrous tumor, Mesenchymal tumor
Background
Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is the most preva lent histologic subtype of thyroid cancer, representing 
80–90% of all cases [1]. It may coexist with other epi thelial thyroid neoplasms, either benign or malignant. 
However, the simultaneous occurrence of PTC and a 
primary mesenchymal tumor is exceedingly rare [2]. Soli tary fibrous tumors (SFT) are mesenchymal neoplasms of Open Access

intermediate malignant potential, rarely occurring in the 
thyroid gland [3]. Only 49 cases of solitary fibrous tumors 
of the thyroid (SFTT) were documented in the literature, 
with just two cases being synchronous with PTC [4, 5]. 
By presenting a synchronous PTC and SFTT case, we aim 
to review the clinical presentation, diagnostic challenges, 
histopathological characteristics, and management strat egies associated with this unusual co-occurrence.
Case presentation
A 46-year-old North African female patient with no prior 
medical history presented with a year-long, indwelling, 
progressively enlarging low cervical swelling. Physical 
examination revealed bilateral palpable thyroid nodules. 
Cervical ultrasound revealed two nodules in the right 
thyroid lobe and one nodule in the left thyroid lobe. The 
first right thyroid nodule, measuring 50  mm, was solid 
hypoechoic, and well demarked, and was classified as 
European Thyroid Imaging and Reporting Data System 
(EU-TIRADS) III. This nodule’s fine-needle aspiration 
(FNA) cytology was classified as Bethesda II, indicating 
a benign lesion. The second right thyroid nodule meas ured 15  mm, and the left was solid hypoechoic with 
irregular margins and microcalcifications; both were 
classified as EU-TIRADS IV. Cytology for the left nod ule was classified as Bethesda VI, diagnostic for PTC. A 
total thyroidectomy with bilateral mediastinal-recurrent 
lymphadenectomy was performed. A gross examination 
of the thyroidectomy specimen revealed a 25  mm yel lowish, granular, and shiny nodule in the lower left lobe. 
The right lobe contained a 55 mm solid, well-demarcated 
nodule, with a calcified upper nodule measuring 20 mm 
(Fig.  1). A frozen section examination of the left nodule 
was concluded to be a papillary carcinoma. Definitive 
histological examination after fixation revealed that the 
left nodule and the 20 mm right nodule corresponded to 
carcinomatous proliferations with papillary architecture. 
The cells were enlarged, with moderately abundant cyto plasm and large, irregular, vesicular, indented nuclei. The 
chromatin was dense and clumped, with small nucleoli 
and a thickened nuclear membrane (Fig.  2). These prolif erations were surrounded by a fibrous capsule that was 
massively invaded, extending into the adjacent paren chyma. Vascular emboli were present. We concluded 
bifocal PTC. Bilateral lymph node metastases from PTC 
were identified. The 55 mm nodule in the right lobe cor responded to a proliferation of spindle cells arranged in 
sheets and wavy or storiform bundles. It was character ized by alternating hypocellular and hypercellular areas 
with a hemangiopericytoma-like vascular pattern. The 
spindle cells had indistinct boundaries with elongated, 
non-atypical nuclei. There was no mitosis (Fig.  3). On 
immunochemistry, the spindle cells showed strong and diffuse positivity for STAT6, CD34, and CD99. They are 
negative for smooth muscle actin, S100, and cytokeratin. 
It was then confirmed to be an SFTT case. The final diag nosis was of synchronous PTC and SFTT. The postopera tive course was uneventful. The patient started to receive 
thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) suppression therapy. 
Radioactive iodine (RAI) therapy was indicated owing to 
the presence of PTC with lymph node metastases. At 9 
months post-surgery, the patient showed no signs of dis tant metastases of either PTC or SFTT.
sections.Discussion:
Discussion
SFTs were first described in 1931 as a primary tumor of 
the pleura [6]. Since then, they have been reported in 
almost all anatomical sites [7]. Currently, extrapleural 
SFTs are the most common, accounting for approxi mately 70% of all cases [7]. SFTs of the head and neck are 
rare, representing less than 0.1% of all SFTs [8, 9]. SFTTs 
are exceptionally rare, with only 49 cases documented in 
the literature.
Only two cases of synchronous PTC with SFTT were 
reported in the literature [4, 5]. In both cases, PTC was 
unifocal, and SFTT was in the contralateral thyroid lobe. 
There were no histological signs of malignancy for SFTTs 
in either case. The first case was that of a 70-year-old 
female patient [4]. The SFTT, which measured 1.7  cm, 
was found in the right lobe, while the PTC, measur ing 2 cm, was in the left lobe. The second case involved 
a 78-year-old male patient [5]. The SFTT, located in the 
right lobe, measured 3.5 cm. The PTC, measuring 1 mm 
in the most significant dimension, was incidentally 
Fig. 1 Gross examination of the total thyroidectomy resection 
specimen: Co ‑occurrence of a solitary fibrous tumor (pink star), 
presenting as a well‑ circumscribed nodule with a fibrous tan cut 
surface and cystic spaces, and a papillary thyroid carcinoma (blue 
arrow), presenting as an ill‑ demarked white ‑yellowish calcified 
nodule
Page 3 of 6
 Ben Thayer et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:595 
 
Fig. 2 Microscopic examination of papillary thyroid carcinoma: A Carcinomatous proliferation with papillary architecture (hematoxylin–eosin, ×20). 
B The tumor cells were enlarged and atypical, with moderately abundant cytoplasm and large, irregular, vesicular, indented nuclei (hematoxylin–
eosin, ×400)
Fig. 3 Microscopic examination of solitary fibrous tumor of the thyroid: A A mesenchymal proliferation made up of spindle cells arranged in sheets 
and storiform bundles entrapping thyroid follicles (hematoxylin–eosin, ×20); B hypercellular areas with a hemangiopericytoma‑like vascular 
pattern (hematoxylin–eosin, ×100); and C spindle cells with indistinct boundaries and elongated, non‑atypical nuclei (hematoxylin–eosin, ×400). D 
Immunohistochemical study: tumor cells show strong and diffuse positivity for STAT6
Page 4 of 6 Ben Thayer et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:595 
identified during the microscopic examination of system atic samples taken from the contralateral thyroid lobe.
On the contrary, in our case, the SFTT was an unex pected finding during the workup of bilateral PTC. 
Although there are insufficient data regarding the patho physiology of the co-occurrence of PTC and SFTT, 
the commonly accepted theory is that PTC and SFTT 
develop independently of one another. Because of the dif ferent histogenesis of the two neoplasms, the occurrence 
of both tumors in the same patient is likely to be coin cidental [4]. PTC originates from the thyroid gland’s fol licular cells, while SFTT arises from mesenchymal cells, 
which belong to a different cellular lineage.
SFTT mainly develops in middle-aged adults, with an 
average age of 54.5 years [28–88] [10]. No cases of SFTT 
have been diagnosed in children or adolescents [10]. 
Similarly to SFTs of other anatomic sites, SFTTs do not 
exhibit sex predilection [11]. They usually present as a 
slow-growing cervical painless mass [11]. Symptoms 
resulting from the compression of adjacent organs, such 
as dyspnea, dysphagia, and dysphonia, are predomi nantly seen in large tumors [11, 12]. In half of the cases, 
the tumor exceeds 5 cm in size, with an average size of 
5.8 cm [2–8, 8–13] [10]. In the case we present, the SFTT 
measured 5.5 cm.
Diagnosing SFTT preoperatively can be difficult 
owing to its rarity and the nonspecific nature of its clini cal and radiological features. Their prevalence is prob ably underestimated since small, slow-growing SFTTs 
lacking concerning imaging features are unlikely to be 
investigated further or may yield a non-diagnostic FNA 
[8]. Ultrasound typically identifies solid hypoechogenic 
well-demarcated nodules, occasionally with cystic echoic 
areas [3–5, 9].
Preoperative SFTT diagnosis using FNA is challeng ing, as the aspirates are often non-diagnostic due to low 
cellularity [11]. In a few cases, unicellular smears may 
show naked nuclei or some dyshesive spindle cells set 
in a background of amorphous eosinophilic collagen ized material [13]. Cytological examination suggested the 
diagnosis in only three cases among the cases reported 
in the literature [3]. Immunohistochemical analysis using 
the anti-CD34 antibody on FNA cytoblock preparation 
samples provides an additional rationale for the diagnos tic process [3]. In our case, FNA cytology was benign and 
showed no signs of SFTT.
On gross examination, SFTT usually manifests as a 
well-circumscribed nodule with a fibrous white to tan cut 
surface [11, 14]. Cystic spaces and hemorrhages might be 
seen [9, 11].
On microscopic examination, SFTs are character ized by an alternance of hypocellular areas (keloidlike collagen) and hypercellular areas, with branching hemangiopericytoma-like vessels [15]. They comprise 
uniform spindle cells with scant cytoplasm, display ing a haphazard patternless, storiform, or desmoid-like 
arrangement [15]. The stroma is collagenous [11]. Nor mal thyroid follicles entrapped within the tumor are 
common and should not be considered an actual invasion 
of the adjacent thyroid parenchyma [9]. Instead, it repre sents a blending or merging of the components [11]. On 
immunohistochemical analysis, tumor cells are immuno reactive for CD34, CD99, BCL2, vimentine, and STAT6. 
They harm TTF1, thyroglobulin, calcitonin, cytokeratin, 
desmin, CD117, PS100, and neuroendocrine markers 
[15].
A gene fusion between NAB2 and STAT6  on chromo some 12q13 has been recognized as the pathognomonic 
molecular aberration in SFT [14, 16]. This NAB2–STAT6 
fusion drives the nuclear translocation of STAT6, which 
can be detected immunohistochemically using an antiSTAT6 antibody [9]. Therefore, this antibody has sub stantially enhanced the diagnostic precision of SFT, 
serving as a highly sensitive and specific marker [3]. It is 
currently regarded as the most reliable tool for diagnosis 
[3]. Only solid and diffuse nuclear expression should be 
considered positive, as focal weak nuclear and cytoplas mic staining can sometimes occur in tumors other than 
SFT [ 11]. In our case, tumor cells showed diffuse and 
intense staining for STAT6.
The diagnosis of SFTT can only be established after 
excluding other thyroid tumors exhibiting spindle cell 
morphology [10]. Distinguishing SFTT from other spin dle cell tumors through morphology alone can be chal lenging [17]. Immunohistochemical analysis is the sole 
diagnostic tool to differentiate SFTT from other mim icking spindle cell lesions [9]. Epithelial neoplasms such 
as PTC, follicular adenoma, follicular carcinoma, and 
medullary carcinoma occasionally exhibit a spindled 
appearance, mimicking SFTT [9]. Spindle cells in these 
tumors are considered metaplastic, showing positivity for 
TTF-1, cytokeratin, and thyroglobulin, with no expres sion of STAT6 or CD34 [9]. PTC with fibromatosis-like 
stroma was the primary differential diagnosis to rule out 
in our case, given the presence of two other nodules cor responding to PTC. It consists of a variant of PTC fea turing a prominent spindle cell component. Spindle cells 
are commonly arranged in interlacing fascicles within a 
collagenous matrix, which can give the tumor an appear ance similar to an SFTT, especially when the epithelial 
component is inconspicuous [11].
In contrast to SFTT, the stromal component of PTC 
with desmoid-type fibromatosis shows positivity for 
smooth muscle actin and negativity for CD34 [11]. 
Medullary thyroid carcinoma may present a spindle cell 
component. However, unlike SFTT, these cells express 
Page 5 of 6
 Ben Thayer et al. Journal of Medical Case Reports          (2024) 18:595 
 
keratin, calcitonin, and neuroendocrine markers [11]. 
Mesenchymal spindle cell tumors, including peripheral 
nerve sheath tumors (PNSTs), neurofibromas, schwanno mas, leiomyomas, and leiomyosarcomas, though rare in 
the thyroid, should also be considered in the differential 
diagnosis [3, 10]. It is the immunohistochemical analysis 
that will enable an accurate diagnosis.
Although most SFTTs are benign, histologic signs of 
malignancy might be seen in a few cases, and some histo logic features of malignancy may be proposed, suggesting 
more aggressive behavior. In 1998, Vallat-Decouvelaere et 
al. proposed histologic features of malignancy suggesting 
a more aggressive behavior including: (i) high cellular ity, (ii) cytological atypia, (iii) high mitotic count (> 4/10 
HPF), and (iv) tumor necrosis or infiltrating margins [18]. 
The World Health Organization’s classification of tumors 
of endocrine organs identified pronounced cellular atypia 
and a high mitotic index as key histological indicators 
of malignancy of SFTTs. However, the clinical course of 
SFT is challenging to predict solely on the basis of histo morphological features [9]. Therefore, malignancy assess ment is based on prediction models, with the modified 
Demicco score being the most validated [3]. It catego rizes patients into three risk groups (low, intermediate, 
and high) on the basis of age (< 55 years or ≥ 55  years), 
tumor size (cm; < 5, 5–10, 10–15, or ≥ 15), mitotic count 
(per 10 high-power fields; 0, 1–3, or ≥ 4), and tumor 
necrosis (< 10% or ≥ 10%)[19]. In our case, the SFTT was 
classified as having a low risk of malignancy according to 
this score.
A thyroid lobectomy may be sufficient for an isolated 
SFTT, provided there is no suspicion of malignancy, 
including the invasion of surrounding structures [14]. In 
the current case, apart from the SFTT, there were two 
nodules with preoperative cytology classified as Bethesda 
VI (CPT), prompting an immediate total thyroidectomy. 
TSH suppression therapy is not warranted in managing 
SFTT since the tumor cells are of stromal origin [14, 20]. 
The use of adjuvant chemotherapy or external radiation 
therapy, even for malignant tumors, is still debated [20, 
21]. In our case, TSH suppression therapy was prescribed 
for synchronous PTC, while radioactive iodine (RAI) 
therapy was indicated owing to the presence of lymph 
node metastases from PTC.
Most SFTTs have a favorable outcome [5 ]. Similar to 
SFTs in other locations, SFTTs require long-term clini cal follow-up [11]. Among the 49 cases reported, only 2 
showed evidence of recurrence and distant metastases 
[3, 20]. Both cases exhibited histologic signs of malig nancy: increased cellularity, atypia, numerous mitoses, 
and tumor necrosis in the first case and increased 
cellularity with 16 mitoses per 10 high-power fields in the second case. The first patient developed local 
recurrence and bilateral lung metastases 5 months 
after surgery [20]. Adjuvant radiotherapy was recom mended but declined by the patient [20]. The second 
patient presented with hepatic and lung metastases 12 
and 14  months, respectively, postoperatively [3 ]—the 
hepatic metastasis was treated with cryoablation [3 ]. 
No treatment was provided for the pulmonary metas tases [ 3]. In our case, no signs of distant metastasis 
were detected 9 months postoperatively.
Conclusion
SFTTs are exceedingly rare. However, they should 
always be considered in the differential diagnosis of 
thyroid spindle cell lesions. Although they usually have 
an indolent course, recurrence and distant metastasis 
might be seen exceptionally. Therefore, long-term clini cal follow-up must be insured. We presented the third 
case of synchronous PTC and SFTT. The co-occurrence 
of these tumors is likely to be incidental. However, fur ther studies are needed to assess the physiopathology 
and molecular alterations of this association.

Declarations
Ethics approval and consent to participate
Our institute does not require ethical committee approval for retrospective 
case reports.
Consent for publication
Written informed consent was obtained from the patient’s next ‑of‑kin for 
publication of this case report and any accompanying images. A copy of the 
written consent is available for review by the Editor ‑in‑Chief of this journal.
